repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Feedback from this PR was that deprecating `vim.tbl_filter()` is too large of a change to make without doing it all at once with other `vim.tbl_*` functions.

As such, consider just "soft-deprecating" these functions by noting this plan for eventual removal in the docs.

Original PR:
> ## Problem
> 
> Once #37821 is merged, there will be three different overlapping ways in the standard library to filter a list: `Iter:filter()`, `vim.tbl_filter()`, and `vim.list.filter()`.
> 
> ## Solution
> 
> Deprecate `vim.tbl_filter()`.
> 
> Part of #24572.
> 
> Note: until #37821 is merged, tests will fail, since this PR depends on the existence of `vim.list.filter()`.

comment_data.body: @lewis6991 I'm curious to hear your thoughts on this one (I know that you're not a huge fan of `vim.iter`).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2079,13 +2079,19 @@ vim.tbl_extend({behavior}, {...})                           *vim.tbl_extend()*
 vim.tbl_filter({fn}, {t})                                   *vim.tbl_filter()*
     Filter a table using a predicate function
 
+    This function is planned for eventual removal. Consider |Iter:filter()|

comment_data.body: Of note: once there are other options as replacements, we can list them here as well. If `vim.list.filter()` is merged, we can document it here.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2079,13 +2079,19 @@ vim.tbl_extend({behavior}, {...})                           *vim.tbl_extend()*
 vim.tbl_filter({fn}, {t})                                   *vim.tbl_filter()*
     Filter a table using a predicate function
 
+    This function is planned for eventual removal. Consider |Iter:filter()|

comment_regular_data.body: Should this wait until there's a plan for lightweight dict table functions? Even if vim.tbl_filter has problems with its output, it does at least iterate through all keys.

Since the behavior of `vim.tbl_filter()` on non-lists works in a very non-useful way, I don't think removing it would affect that much (does anyone use that function to filter a non-list table?). `vim.iter()` can iterate tables in a much nicer way. A non-iterator version (without the problems of `vim.tbl_filter()`) is a good idea (`vim.table.filter()`), but imo it's not a blocking issue for merging this PR.

> Since the behavior of `vim.tbl_filter()` on non-lists works in a very non-useful way, I don't think removing it would affect that much (does anyone use that function to iterate a non-list table?). 

At least not in the plugin space I'd think. Scanned through a couple I have and I only saw it used to filter lists.

That said, I did get 117 plugin results even after filtering out docs, so bumping vim.deprecate to v0.14 seems like the right idea.

> `vim.iter()` can iterate tables in a much nicer way. A non-iterator version (without the problems of `vim.tbl_filter()`) is a good idea (`vim.table.filter()`), but imo it's not a blocking issue for merging this PR.

vim.iter() definitely helps, but it still returns the results as a list of string tuples rather than the original structure.

I think you're jumping the gun here a bit; I would rather have a compelling story for _all_ list/table/iter interfaces before forcing downstream to adapt _multiple times_.

(Specifically, I had looked at your PR and decided that I would keep using `vim.tbl_filter` because it's more convenient and performant for my purposes -- I don't need to care about non-integer keys in my use case as I have full control of the pipeline. I am not happy about being forced to switch -- which means _yet another_ single-function compatibility shim to drag around for months to years -- just for the sake of it.)

> I think you're jumping the gun here a bit; I would rather have a compelling story for _all_ list/table/iter interfaces before forcing downstream to adapt _multiple times_.

Makes sense. Since `vim.tbl_filter()` will still be eventually removed, what are your thoughts on mentioning this in the docs? (as suggested in #24572)
I understand that deprecating `vim.tbl_filter()` at this point in time is not a good idea. I have fully changed this PR to simply mention the plans of #24572 in the docs.

Again, I think this is jumping the gun, and I don't see what problem this change solves (in itself). Why don't we wait until we have the `vim.list`/`vim.table` story sorted out and _then_ start deprecating (when we know _what_ we want to deprecate and in whose favor)?

> Again, I think this is jumping the gun, and I don't see what problem this change solves (in itself). Why don't we wait until we have the `vim.list`/`vim.table` story sorted out and _then_ start deprecating (when we know _what_ we want to deprecate and in whose favor)?

Going back through the discussion in the list.filter PR, it feels like there is a cluster of concerns around flexibility/parity with other languages, and a cluster of concerns around simplicity/performance.

Given that vim.iter focuses on the former, and list.unique/list.bisect focus on the latter, I think that would be a good frame to build the overall user story around. And I think that framing could also be extended consistently to vim.table. 

EDIT: As an example, unless I'm mistaken, Neovim doesn't ship with built-in pure Lua shallow copy functions. So vim.list.copy() and vim.table.copy() would be on-target use cases for those namespaces.

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: docs(lua): soft-deprecate `vim.tbl_filter()` and `vim.tbl_map()`
